Foreign Minister de Charette noted that my visit 'allows us to tum the page and write new ones'. I can only agree with those sentiments. There are positive foundations to build on. Our trade relationship is a good one, as is our investment relationship. We have a long history of cooperation in international affairs. The most recent example of that was the cooperation between Australia and France to bring about a comprehensive test ban treaty, which was open for signature in New York on 24 September. We do have very extensive people to people contacts with France. While I was in Paris, I took the opportunity of raising with the French government the establishment of visa-free travel for Australians in France. I know the requirement to obtain a visa to visit France is a significant irritant for Australians who want to go to that country, be it for business or pleasure, and many of course do. The French government, in light of the introduction of our electronic travel authority, is giving consideration now to providing visa-free travel for Australians into France. Tuesday, 8 October 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4943 Tuesday, 8 October 1996 Sitting suspended from 4.32 to 4.40 p.m. for 30 seconds, I believe that lowe it to the Main Committee to extend an apology, not because I deliberately or even unwittingly arrived late but in fact because, as you are aware, we were all at the same meeting. I stand simply so that there is no reflection on the honourable member for Adelaide (Ms Worth)-who, as I left the meeting following you, said she was supposed to be in the Main Committee. I said, 'Don't worry, Trish, I will be there to cover for you,' not realising that she had a 4.30 p.m. responsibility. I arrived, imagining I was to follow the honourable member for Denison( Mr Kerr). I have, in fact, unwittingly caused this delay in the Main Committee, and the delay should not reflect unfairly on Ms Worth. I would say to the Main Committee that I did wait for two minutes which I should not have done, to extend the period of grace, but then I had to come in. A quorum not being present, I had then to adjourn. I might say that I adjourned to 4.40 p.m. to ensure that there was adequate time for a quorum to be present because, if I had reoccupied the chair and a quorum had not been present, I would have been forced, according to standing orders, to adjourn the sitting of the committee until tomorrow. Second Reading Debate resumed from 19 September, on motion by Mr Costello: That the bill be now read a second time. upon which Mr Gareth Evans moved by way of amendment: That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: 'whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House notes that: (1) the Budget betrays the Australian promise of working towards a more fair, just, inclusive and united society; (2) the Budget is both mindless and heartless, and its prescriptions are not what the Australian economy needs at present; (3) the Budget will have a savagely contractionary impact on economic growth and make impossible the job creation necessary to reduce Australia's still unacceptably high level of unemployment; (4) with stronger economic growth the Budget could be restored to underlying balance over the life of this Parliament through a much more moderate program of fiscal consolidation; (5) the spending cuts and tax increases contained in the Budget are, on the evidence of the Government's own Budget Papers, not necessary to reduce the Commonwealth Government's debtto-GDP ratio and will not produce a significant improvement in the current account deficit; (6) the Budget not only offers no hope to the unemployed but actively harms their prospects of finding a job by cutting labour market programs and privatising the previously publicly provided employment service function of the CES;
title: Adjournment Funds

speaker: Mr Deputy Speaker ( Mr Nehl) Took The Chair At 4.32 P.m.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Deputy Speaker
theText: There being no quorum, I will resume the chair at 4.40 p.m.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Andrew (Wakefield) (4.40 P.m.)
theText: Mr Deputy Speaker, if I may have your indulgence
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Deputy Speaker
theText: I thank the honourable member for Wakefield for his courtesy.4944 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 8 October 1996 (7) the Budget will have unfair and unjust consequences for the struggling and disadvantaged in our midst-the poor, the old, the sick, indigenous Australians and newly-arrived migrants; (8) the many spending cuts concemed with education and training, research and development, trade development (including breaches of promise with respect to EMDG, ITES and lAMP), production bounties, and other business support, will be counter-productive in their longer term consequences; (9) there is deception involved in the family tax package contained in the Budget, whereby what the Prime Minister appears to be putting into one pocket is for most middle Australian families being taken right out of the other by the Treasurer in higher education fees, Austudy changes, higher nursing home charges, higher fees and charges; (10) there are many breaches of Coalition election promises contained in this Budget, which amount to over $17 billion over four years, and which will cause hardship, insecurity, and dismay for millions of Australians; (11) the Budget involves a massive betrayal of regional Australia through the abolition of the $150 million regional development programme, large cuts to road funding, the closure of regional Government offices such as Medicare and CES offices, and the cuts to the ABC and university funding; (12) the mean-spirited decision to introduce large, up-front entry fees and massively increased daily fees for nursing homes, and increase user-charges will harm elderly Australians; (13) the abolition of Childcare Operational Subsidies will impact heavily upon community based child care centres; (14) the reduction of $800 million over four years in public hospital funding will cause longer waiting lists for the sick and reduce the quality of hospital and medical assistance for millions of people; (15) the Budget involves a breaking of the Government's so called 'core' commitment to maintain Medicare in its entirety through cuts to rebates for numerous items under Medicare; (16) the cruel decision to abolish the Commonwealth Dental Health Programme will cause serious problems for the less well off; (17) harsh and promise-breaking decisions will force Australian families to pay substantially more for the cost of their prescription medicines; (18) the massive funding cuts to education, the increased HECS charges and AUSTUDY changes will penalise the less well-off; (19) the Budget's comprehensive and ideological assault on the public sector will cost 10,500 jobs in 1996-97 alone; (20) the Government has failed to honour its election commitment to maintain the environment budget and to provide an additional $84 million in the 1996-97 Budget, instead cutting by 13 per cent the environmental budget and forward estimates; (21) the reckless decision to reduce funding for the National Highway by $622 million over four years, breaches a clear Coalition election commitment at the 1996 election, and with other decisions will reduce the level of public infrastructure investment, especially in regional Australia; (22) the decision to impose a 500 per cent increase in the taxation arrangements for visits to the Great Barrier Reef will discourage tourism and cost jobs in Queensland; (23) the Government has failed to honour its promise to not cut Australia's foreign aid beyond the election commitment to abolish the DIFF program, and in doing so will allow the estimated ODAlGDP ratio for Australia in 1996-97 to fall to 0.29 per cent; (24) the Government has failed to honour its election promise that Defence expenditure would not be cut, whilst cutting $165 million from the 1995 Defence Budget estimates for 1996-97, and reducing Defence expenditure as a percentage of GDP to its lowest level since 1939; (25) the mean-spirited and discriminatory approach to migrants and ethnic communities will harm outworkers, hurt newly-arrived migrants and refugees, cut humanitarian aid and penalise asylum seekers; Tuesday, 8 October 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4945 (26) the substantial cuts to ATSIC and to indigenous-related Commonwealth programs represent a massive setback to the process of reconciliation in Australia; (27) the savage cuts to the ABC, of $209 million over four years, are in complete breach of the Coalition's solemn election promise to maintain existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC; (28) the Budget has failed to honour the promise to maintain levels of arts funding and spend an additional $60 million over three years; and (29) the Government's plan to substantially increase Commonwealth court and tribunal fees, coupled with deep cuts to legal aid, will result in a severe curtailment of access to justice by many Australians. ' the Opposition ( Mr Gareth Evans), there are a number of references to the impact that the budget measures would have on those who make Australia their country of settlement. The main burden of this budget is, of course, on cost recovery from that sector, but the damage goes deeper because it is compounded with changes to settlement policies which run quite counter to the national interest and also to the interests of those who have made Australia their home. IfI begin with the direct budget measures, I suppose an overall summary of the budget would be to say that it takes something over $1 billion from the area of immigration and immigration support, whilst it boasts of spending some $64 million over four years: a net reduction of expenditure in this area of something of the order of $950 million. There are boastful announcements in the budget of trifling additional expenditure, but they are overwhelmed with new charges. The government says it will spend an additional $17 million on English language programs over four years, but it is going to slug users of those services over twice that amount during the same period. That is a tax on the coalition's commitment, which they proudly boasted before the election would ensure that all migrants would have the opportunity to gain effective communication. The rise proposed to each individual from $2,205 to $5,500 is in fact a deterrent to new settlers learning what the coalition called, before the election, a common language which is the glue of a cohesive nation. The government is planning to raise an additional $16.5 million in migrant health service charges whilst cutting back access. The family reunion program, which the government promised to reject, is cut; yet the costs for visa and other filing applications will yield over $37 million in 1996-97. The cost of visitor visas is up 200 per cent, the fee for application for change of status to permanent resident is up 120 per cent, and even the fee to become an Australian citizen has increased. Spending on multiculturalism, which was formerly the responsibility of the now defunct Office of Multicultural Affairs which was formerly in the Prime Minister's Department, is more than halved. The commitment to work with the Federation of Ethnic Communities Council of Australia-FECCA-is at least in doubt. With respect to FECCA, the policy of the government would appear, certainly to most observers, to be no more than that of intimidation. The budget for FECCA has not been resolved. On two occasions now the organisation has been told that decisions relating to its funding are being postponed pending further consideration and further reviews, and the organisation still has had no advice as to whether or not it will have its funding at the end of this year. The minister, in fact, has
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Kerr (Denison) (4.43 P.m.)
theText: In the amendment proposed by the Deputy Leader of4946 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 8 October 1996 announced a review which only commences its work in December and the budget for the organisation runs out at about the same time. The government, at a time when the subject of immigration and the implications for Australia of choices being made by this government are at the forefront of every newspaper, every editorial, every columnist, is holding an axe of funding over the principal body that speaks for ethnic Australians. It is not resolving that and I regard that as a complete travesty and a failure of this government to act in a way which is honourable. Mr Ruddock, Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, boasted of adding multiculturalism to his portfolio. In his charter of responsibility on multiculturalism, he has said nothing on this across all portfolios, a practice observed by previous governments. There is nothing in the budget that refers to the way in which the interests and concerns of people from different cultural backgrounds are going to be recognised and respected in the different works of the various agencies. To me, the failure to produce such a document is a stinging indictment of this government's claim to speak for all Australians. With regard to the $10 million promised before the election with respect to racial vilification education, only $5 million is committed, with the rest to follow a 'review'. But nothing appears in the forward estimates, which means, of course, that the government is set to break yet another election promise. With respect to a racial vilification campaign, spending $5 million on that is akin to spitting against a hurricane when the Prime Minister has sat mute for so long while the whirlwinds of racial intolerance are fanned. His conspicuous silence remained to such a degree that people of goodwill, even on his own side of politics, felt the need to speak out, and to speak out in terms that can only be regarded as those of the greatest of alarm. In short, Mr Ruddock is boasting about spending $64 million while, by gutting, slashing and ramping up charges-and add the recoveries intended to be made, particularly by the extension of the waiting period for two years and a number of other measures announced by the government and implemented in this budget-he will grab something over a billion dollars. The government proposes that new settlers not have access to a whole range of education, labour market and social security support. They have made, in recognition of the damage that this will cause, a token additional contribution to emergency relief organisations-private charitable organisations-to pick up the broken pieces that their policy recognises will follow from that heartless approach. It is not only heartless, it is irresponsible. It is irresponsible because, if one looks at the time when people make a success of coming to this country, forming a new future, building the roots that enable them to go on and make their family's and their own success in this country, the first two years are the critical periods. If there are savings to be made, project them forward. But the first couple of years when people first arrive are inevitably going to be periods when people are most at risk of finding themselves in difficulties. If Australia is unable to provide for them the kinds of opportunities necessary to make effective settlement, to help them find educational skills if their skills do not prove to be adequate, to help them into labour market programs if their hopes are not met by employment--or help them find some emergency relief if their circumstances do not prove as they hope-then we are building up problems for the future. We are building up a large store of problems for future generations by what is a short-sighted and penny-pinching approach. Tuesday, 8 October 1996 MAIN COMMfITEE 4947 The real cost to Australians is the serious long-term problems this will leave us as our inheritance. To severely restrict access to essential needs for successful settlement in health, education and the opportunity to enter the labour market and be a productive member of society will carry a price we wish we did not have to pay. This is retrograde, myopic and simply bad policy. It makes short-term gains at the expense of migrants but risks big problems and high social costs for the future of all Australians. Mr Deputy Speaker, one of the areas, of course, where the impact is most to be felt is in the area of English language. Successive governments have expanded services available to new arrivals to this country to make sure that people do acquire effective English language skills so that they can make effective settlement. In its pledge before the last election, the coalition criticised the failure of the former government to expand those services adequately and indicated it was pledged to additional funding and to make certain that those services were more readily available to, as they put it at that time, ensure that the glue that makes for our social cohesiveness holds. But what do we find in the area of English language programs? What we do find is that in its first budget, the Howard government has announced a 250 per cent increase for access to English language classes under the adult migrant education program. But the fee will rise from $2,205 to $5,500 at 1 January 1997, with an interim rise to $4,405 at 1 October of this year. That has simply put the program out of reach for many migrants. The minister, Philip Ruddock, fools no-one with his announcement of additional funding of $17.6 million over four years. That was a pledged amount the minister claims that was delivered on in this budget. By the time the first instalment of that money is paid in 1 July 1997 the Howard government will have collected $11.6 million in user charges from the same program, up from $2.8 million in 1995-96. What you see just in that short period of time, before any money is paid out, is that a collection of $11 V2 million will be made and then the additional fees that are being charged will more than double, on a recurrent basis, the new expenditure. The language in the media release by the minister gives rise for concern about the future of the program. He speaks of consultations with migrants, service providers, state and territory governments and the wider community. It seems that this is setting up a preamble for what are now ambiguously called reviews, which are intended to bring to an end programs which the government feels less than comfortable with. Apart from migrants from English speaking backgrounds, many skilled migrants with much to offer our economy will be severely disadvantaged. Again, it is not the individual disadvantage to the particular new arrival that we ought to be most concerned about, notwithstanding that we should all, I think, have a compassionate response to people who have made such a wrenching decision to come from another place and to make their new home in this country as a permanent member of our community. I suspect there is none more traumatic, none more complex than the decision to actually leave the land of one's birth and to move to a new country to intend to become a permanent resident of that country and to face so many great changes that inevitably confront you. Take all those concerns into hand as the individuals battle to make a success of it-as everyone inevitably does when they make that choice-as they arrive from overseas; put to one side any compassion for people who themselves will be disadvantaged by the government decisions that will leave them without adequate social security support if, by some 4948 MAIN COMMITIEE Tuesday, 8 October 1996 misadventure, their hopes prove unfounded. Put to one side any concern about the people who find themselves with a need to improve their training to enter the job market. Put to one side the difficulties people find in playing an effective part in their own communities where they have made their home if they do not have adequate English language skills. But think of the larger long-term cost to this community. Think of those long-term costs. Penny-pinching in this area is intensely counterproductive. The measures that are intended by this government to set up brick walls to those who come here to enter the work force, making access to English language programs more difficult, will lead to consigning many to despair and long-term dependence on social welfare. The simplistic justification of full cost recovery ignores the real benefits that such programs produce. The adult migrant education program has a solid track record of success and would be directly responsible for ensuring many new settlers' successful entry to the work force. And, again, the real cost of this bad policy will be manifest in future years. It is certainly possible, and ought to be possible, to contemplate a different outcome from this, especially if considered with many other measures proposed by the Howard government. We ought not to use mechanisms of this nature to seek to deter people coming to Australia. The Prime Minister today said that the government remained committed to non-discriminatory immigration policies. It hardly makes sense in that environment to create barriers of this nature which plainly will disadvantage people who lack fluent English language skills to make successful settlement. It consigns those now in this country and those to come to great difficulty in making that successful transition. I might also, in the little time that is left to me, reflect on the nature of the changes to the program itself. The government has recently introduced regulations which propose profound and unprecedented changes to the way in which Australia will proceed in the selection of those who come to this country. There is relatively little difference between the two parties in terms of the size of the intake. Pandering, I believe, to a sentiment that exists in the community, the Prime Minister has couched his description of that intake as a slash in the migration program, and the Deputy Prime Minister said that the government had taken steps because the program had been out of control. The truth is that the program of the current government is about average for the previous term of the Keating government which, in its own term, was the lowest post-war migration period in Australia's history. So we have no significant argument about numbers between us, but we do have very significant arguments about the way in which the program is being manipulated. Some people, I think, are already making suggestions to accommodate outcomes which are intended to make it less possible for people from some parts of the globe to come to this country; outcomes which have been designed and manipulated in that deliberate manner. Others are more charitably saying that it simply has that accidental effect. But whatever the account of that is-and that debate will happen in the discussion about the regulations and in wider forums than this-I think that I should focus on one particular savage decision of the government, and that is with respect to spouses. With no evidence other than the lead-out of anecdotal stories of abuse of the spouse arrangements, the government has proposed that from henceforth, the right of Australians to marry people of their own choice will be abridged. It has never happened before. In Senate Estimates, it was made clear by officers of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs that there is no evidence of widespread abuse of the spouse visa system. Tuesday, 8 October 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4949 And to the extent that sporadic and occasional abuse occurs, I have assured the government that we stand ready with them to act against it. But there is no case whatsoever in a free country such as ours to say to any Australian citizen, or to permanent residents, that the right that they have to meet, marry and choose their partner for their future ought to be abridged. What the government is proposing to do is to cap spouse visas. That is to say that, at a particular time, no more Australians will be permitted the privilege of bringing their marriage partner to this country. I regard that as outrageous. And the greatest condemnation of that actually comes not from me, but in the words of the now Minister for Immigration ( Mr Ruddock). When legislation which first allowed capping of any visa categories came before the parliament, what he said, with respect to a specific decision to make it plain that that capping could not apply to spouses, was: The Minister has agreed to two specific amendments. One was to exclude the immediate family category-that is, spouses, dependent children and aged parents. I regard it as absolutely unconscionable for a government to say half way through a year, 'We have enough spouses in now, we are going to close off the category and no more people in that category can come to Australia-no more husbands and wives, no more dependent children, or aged parents'. I am glad that the Minister has made the decision to exclude those groups. We have saved the Government great agony had it persisted in that area. Of course, it was never the government's intention whatsoever to persist in that area. The amendments were moved to make absolutely clear th<1t no party in this parliament would tolerate that abuse. And now the government in which Mr Ruddock is a minister comes before us to do what he has condemned as unconscionable. It is a disgrace. in this appropriation debate I cannot open my remarks on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) without reflecting, at least briefly, on some of the remarks made by the member for Denison( Mr Kerr), the shadow minister for immigration. He has used all of his legal skills to very carefully avoid doing anything that would suggest that he was branding members of the government as having racist views. But while he has used all his legal skills to avoid that statement he has nonetheless skirted around the question of immigration and implied that, from time to time, racist attitudes have determined what the government's priorities will be. I have to flatly deny and refute any such allegation. Anyone from the opposition or the government who knows Mr Kerr interjectingpoint now that he has introduced it into the debate. But no-one from the opposition or the government, knowing the Prime Minister or the Minister for Immigration, could suggest for a moment that there is any racial discrimination in any of the attitudes that they have indicated, either before or after these budgetary measures. The member for Denison provokes me by going on to suggest that in 1988 the Prime Minister, who was not then in that office, had made remarks that the member for Denison alleges were racist. I would equally, and as flatly, refute any such allegation. Minister, and anyone who witnessed question time today would be well aware of the fact that the Prime Minister views all races with equanimity, and that he takes the simple view that once

theText: While I welcome the opportunity to participate

theText: The member for Denison invites me, quite frankly, to pick up that very

speaker: Mr Kerr
theText: I said he called for a reduction in Asian migration.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Andrew
theText: I know the Prime Minister, everyone in this parliament knows the Prime4950 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 8 October 1996 someone is in Australia and is recognised as an Australian the law should apply equally to them and to all Australians. Mr Kerr interjectingnumbers-which has bipartisan support, which has been recognised by the opposition as being a responsible view to take of our present immigration policy-will in some way have racist overtones and lead to an emphasis on migration from one area of the globe rather than another. Let me equally refute that sort of allegation. All that the government has done in relation to immigration in these budget papers is to pick up what has been the call from the former government, in a bipartisan sense, to reduce the number of migrants freely coming into Australia-not to reduce a particular category. If that were the proposal I would be indignant in my opposition. Mr Deputy Speaker, you know, I know and I believe every responsible member knows, that all the government seeks to do is to offer a fair and internationally defensible immigration policy. For that reason I also take issue with the member for Denison. In his opening remarks he has suggested that the two-year waiting period proposed for migrants who come into Australia, which will make it more difficult for them to access Commonwealth benefits, is in some way an unfair measure-as if the government were proposing to take new migrants who come into Australia and deny them access to all benefits without forewarning. The simple reality is that every migrant coming into Australia beyond this budgetary period knows that they will come in to a two-year waiting period. All that the government has said is that the responsibility that every new Australian will face is the responsibility of making provision for their settlement in Australia for a period of two years. It would be very difficult in my electorate, and I suspect in any other electorates across the nation, including the electorate of the member for Denison, to find electors who are offended by that. I have a large migrant community in my electorate; an electorate which is made up of a number of horticultural crops which are labour intensive and which for that reason have attracted people with a relatively low capital base and a willingness to work. Within my migrant community there is overwhelming support for the proposal that people should wait two years before being able to access these sorts of Commonwealth benefits. Given that my migrant community supports it, you can be sure that most people across the nation feel this is a responsible step and most certainly do not see it as having any of the racial overtones implied by the member for Denison. There has been some debate about these appropriation bills being referred to the Main Committee. I want in my opening remarks to say that, given the time that has been spent on these bills in the chamber, the action of the government is entirely appropriate. The appropriation bills are very much about dealing with the economic success that Australia will have and the economic success that the government can generate for the nation over the ensuing 12 months and, indeed, over a longer time frame. The issue that, in fact, has been behind all that motivated the 1996-97 budget is the question simply of debt. No matter what the former government may say, the reality is that they left the books in a deplorable state and the incoming government has no choice but to introduce a budget that has some unpopular measures in order to address the problem of debt.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Andrew
theText: The member for Denison has further suggested that the reduction inTuesday, 8 October 1996 MAIN COMMITIEE 4951 Let me pick up a quote from the independent review of the budget done by the National Farmers Federation. They said this: There has been a significant deterioration in the state of Australia's fiscal position over the past seven years. Measured in underlying tenns the Budget moved from a small surplus in 1988-89 to a peak: deficit of $17.1 billion in 1993-94. Urgent refonn was needed to repair this situation. The 1996-97 Budget represents a sensible and well balanced commitment to the Government's objective of achieving a balance in the underlying Budget over the course of the economic cycle. It is likely to boost business confidence, support lower interest rates, and provide the foundation for ongoing low inflationary growth. I do not want to take all my debating time simply quoting from the National Farmers Federation, but the document went on to say: The Budget strategy clearly identifies one of the major structural impediments to sustainable economic growth-a high structural current account deficit, as a result of a deficiency in national saving. There can be no doubt that the deterioration in public finances has been partly responsible for this development. In this context, it is simply not acceptable, after four years of solid economic growth, that Australia should have been running an underlying deficit of over $10 billion. This is not the view of the government's Treasurer, it is the view of the National Farmers Federation, which on behalf of the primary producers of Australia was reviewing the budget statement that makes up these appropriation bills. The simple reality is that as independent a source as the retiring Governor of the Reserve Bank, Mr Bernie Fraser, has said that there is no more urgent need facing this nation than addressing the underlying debt and removing, so far as possible, the $10 billion deficit. Around this appropriation debate there has been a great deal said about the partial sale of Telstra. Much of this will be addressed later in this chamber and, of course, in the House of Representatives chamber as well. But the simple reality that seems to escape all economic commentators is that the government's enthusiasm for the partial sale of Telstra is entirely motivated not by a proposal to find $1 billion or $1.2 billion to spend on the environment but by a desire to find $7 billion to address our overseas debt and to reduce the overseas debt by something like 10 per cent. What the now opposition cannot escape is that when they came to office overseas borrowings in Australia ran at something like $23 billion, and when they left office overseas borrowings in Australia ran at something like $185 billion. I am the first to concede-and I would not want the member for Fowler( Mr Ted Grace) to feel that he has been misrepresented-that of that $125 billion, much of it is made up of private borrowings. But the reality is that, of that $185 billion, probably somewhere between $70 billion and $85 billion is made up of government borrowings. And in order to trim those government borrowings by 10 per cent and so make the economic objectives of the government more achievable, we need the partial sale of Telstra. That is the motivation that has been lost in the nonsense that has been run about using the Telstra moneys for the environment when, in reality, as a member of the government, I want that partial sale to reduce my overseas outlays and so give me an opportunity to realistically reduce interest rates within Australia. What does this budget do? We need to recognise that one of the things that the budget does is to effectively reduce the proportion of GDP that is going to the government. Allow me to quote one paragraph from the Parliamentary Research Service. On reflecting on the budget, the research service under 'Outlays' said: Total outlays for 1996-97 are estimated to be $129 billion or 25.2 per cent of GDP, compared with $126 billion in 1995-96, or 26.1 per cent of GDP. What the government can claim to have achieved while 4952 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 8 October 1996 addressing the debt, is to have taken less of the GDP resources and addressed them to government services. That is no mean feat. In addition to that, the government has done something about what foreign ownership is effectively undoing in Australia. In 1989, when the previous government was in power, there was something like $53 billion poured into Australia to acquire Australian assets. In 1996, when the previous government was no longer in power, $190 billion had been poured into Australia acquiring Australian assets for foreign ownership. Some of that was the result of policies of the former government. The government, for example, sold such facilities as Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank and so, effectively, injected one way or another additional foreign ownership into Australia. Critics will say, 'But surely the proposal of the now government to partially sell Telstra will also inject additional foreign currency into Australia.' There is some truth in that, but the previous government sold those resources without-as my statistics illustrate-reducing the debt. The Howard government commits itself to using the resources of the partial sale of Telstra solely for the reduction of debt. That is a significant difference. We are doing something about pruning our outlays and unless we prune those outlays-the point made by the National Farmers Federation, and reinforced by Mr Bernie Fraser-we will bequeath to our children an impossible economic situation. I am one of those who have a vested interest in the partial sale of Telstra because I happen to represent the electorate in South Australia most served by the Murray-Darling Basin. It could be said that I am ignoring some of the opportunities that the environment package would offer for the Murray-Darling Basin by putting the emphasis on paying off the debt, but the facts are that this budgetary package targets more money for the Murray-Darling Basin, quite apart from the money that will be generated as a result of the partial sale of Telstra. An additional $4.5 million goes into the Murray-Darling Basin, money that is essentially needed for the Hume Dam, as was highlighted in question time today by the question on the future of the Hume Dam from the member for Indi( Mr Liebennan), who pointed out that there has been a movement in the dam wall that will require further engineering modification. That will cost more money. That puts some of his irrigators at risk as the total capacity of the Hume Dam is run down. While it does not put my South Australian irrigators at risk, it does mean that the flooding that currently exists in the River Murray will extend over a prolonged period. But there are additional difficulties. The additional difficulties are simply that we will then have a Hume Dam with a lesser catchment than may be responsible, going into next winter and next summer; a Hume Dam that needs to be filled, if the irrigators represented by the member for Indi are to be assured of their irrigation supply in a year that may not have the same level of rainfall as we have experienced this winter. I have focused on those remarks because there is a complication that is a largely related one also occurring for South Australian irrigators. Not many people in this chamber will be aware of the fact that, for South Australian irrigators, Lake Victoria-which provides the sort of effective safety valve on water availability for South Australia-has also been run down, because wave action has unearthed Aboriginal burial grounds along the edge of the lake. The running down of Lake Victoria-which was done responsibly, to allow for the recovering of those Aboriginal burial grounds with coarser soil at a cost of $1 million, which was provided in the budget-has had, as with the Hume Dam, a long-tenn adverse affect. Tuesday, 8 October 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4953 While Lake Victoria has been run down, 67 years of having Lake Victoria at a particular storage level has meant that water has penetrated the sandhills around the lake, probably for some kilometres. That water is now running back in, so that what is collecting in Lake Victoria is water that is much more saline than any irrigator.or any domestic user can tolerate. The government-or, more accurately, the Murray-Darling Basin Commission-finds itself in a delicate balancing act to meet the reasonable demands of the Aboriginal community to have these burial grounds preserved and, at the same time, to ensure that South Australian irrigators do not have a head of saline water awaiting them. I make those comments because, under this budget, money is provided to the basin. As the Hume Dam is run down, the storage of Lake Victoria-not only for South Australian irrigators but also for New South Wales irrigators-next year may also be at risk, unless the Hume works can be accelerated and there is adequate rainfall to fill that dam. and of course, ultimately, Adelaide's water supply. That is important because, as you will all appreciate, the South Australian irrigators are guaranteed a water allocation which comes from Dartmouth, Hume or Lake Victoria as the case may be; so that, while South Australia may be guaranteed that allocation, any shortage of available water in New South Wales and Victoria further exacerbates the problem of the guarantee that New South Wales and Victorian irrigators have. I make these comments to point out the importance of the budget to addressing the whole question of national debt and the fact that the budget has not ignored those principal environmental issues that need to be addressed in the national interest. There are a number of other comments I wanted to make, particularly about the supermarket to Asia strategy to encourage the sale of horticultural products in that booming market, and the $28 million to extend the Adelaide airport runway and ensure there is greater access to Asian markets, particularly for my growers and irrigators. I also wanted to comment on the enthusiasm the government has shown for the reform of AQIS and for Australia's quarantine measures to ensure that, within Asia, we have a guarantee that whatever vegetable, horticultural, meat and livestock products are provided come with a blue-ribbon guarantee and, equally, that we are secure in the knowledge that any products imported into Australia will not bring with them the pests and diseases that would put at risk our reputation as a clean and green producer. I will not go into the other areas because time will not permit. I am partially responsible for that shortage of time, so may I just say how much I welcome the opportunity to support the government's appropriation measures. the extent to which post-election revelations were accurate about the condition of the Commonwealth deficit for last financial year; that is, 1995-96. Forward costings that were then released demonstrated that the previously concealed effects of expenditure into future years inevitably meant that Labor's legacy would see even more copious bleeding of budgetary red ink unless severe measures to staunch the flow were taken immediately. While the coalition undoubtedly knew before and during the last election campaign that Labor was fudging by concealing the true position, the previous government has given its new successor the near perfect cop-out in the eyes of the public. The coalition was handed a rancour-free opportunity to abandon a whole raft of election promises. At the same time the

speaker: Mr Rocher (Curtin) (5.21 P.m.)
theText: One of the more surprising features of this budget is4954 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 8 October 1996 new government already had the example of Labor over 13 years in government on which to draw. But the true state of the budget for last year, and the deliberate misinformation surrounding it and the forward estimates, makes the coalition's backtracking likely to attract a minimum of political odium. The danger for all Australians is a perception by the government that, despite its broken promises, it can do exactly what it likes into the future, thereby fulfilling prophecies of arrogance which will match that of its predecessor. Someone will have to curb the Treasurer ( Mr Costello) if that is not to happen, and who better than the Prime Minister( Mr Howard). A measure of Australia's tax burden can be seen in the tax takes for the years 1995-96 and 1996-97. speaker: Mr Deputy Speaker ( Mr Nehl)
theText: The honourable member for Curtin has done meTuesday, 8 October 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4955 1995-96 Revenue Item actual** 1996-97 estimate % increase Sales tax 12955 13890 7.2 Excise dutyCrude oil, LPG, 10238 10750 5.0 petroleum Other 2612 2610 (0.1) Customs dutyImports 3124 3010 (3.6) Other taxes, fees 1960 2138 9.1 and fines Total indirect tax 30889 32398 4.0 Non tax revenueInterest 1403 1123 (20.0) Dividends and other 3899 4009 2.8 Total non-tax revenue 5302 5132 (3.2) * SOURCE: Budget Statements 1996-97, Budget Paper No.1 Page 4-28 ** Some totals for 1995-96 do not add up, probably because of Treasury's rounding up and down of figures. $121,660 million-up from $44,795 million in 1983, when Labor first took office. For this year it is estimated to be $130,160 million, an increase over last year of $8,500 million. That increase on its own would have been nearly enough to balance this budget had it not been for expenditure growth locked into current and forward expenditure by Labor. As it is, it seems to have turned out that [he government will get away politically unscathed with breaking its undertakings to not increase taxes-as in fact it has, with Medicare and the superannuation imposts. The 'read my lips' tax undertakings are apparently dismissible as not being 'core' promises. Labor is equally, if not more, culpable because it provided the excuses now being employed by the government. On behalf of all decent, trusting Australians I say, 'A plague on both your houses' . It is hard enough to do the job of an elected representative, without being tagged by mere association as an inveterate liar. It is uncontested conventional wisdom that the tax grab on superannuation funds was pounced on at the last moment, given the government's change of heart about the fuel tax rebate. One can only wonder whether the parliament's virtually unanimous support for an increase in the Medicare tax to buy firearms from the public encouraged the government to go one per cent further, albeit selectively. Why this government continues the charade that encourages the widespread belief that the Medicare so-called levy meets the cost of funding Medicare is beyond comprehension. Because it is a tax on income the levy should be integrated into the more progressive income tax regime. It would also be one way of simplifying the tax system.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Rocher
theText: Last financial year, revenue from all sources, before asset sales, totalled4956 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 8 October 1996 Both tax hikes in the budget expand the opportunity for future windfalls to revenue by way of bracket creep. It must be a source of despair for government in times of low inflation that the previous bounty from bracket creep is diminished. Perhaps the government realises that, by creating unindexed income brackets where none previously existed, as in the cases of new imposts on contributions to superannuation and Medicare, new growth taxes are there for the taking. But where does it stop? The superannuation funds were already a milch cow under Labor. Now that the coalition has made its initial bid for the lucrative spoils and has set a precedent, what logical impediment is there in the way of a future government of any persuasion to, say, lower the threshold, firstly, to be set at an unindexed income of $70,000 per annum in the case of the super tax? As it is now no longer to be a matter of principle that a particular level of income should be a determinant because the precedent has been set, it becomes a question of how much can be raised rather than whether further income tested imposts can be levied. The same concern about the behaviour of a future government surrounds new ground to be broken by partial income testing of the Medicare levy. It is now a pretty safe bet that in the lifetimes of most in this parliament the income threshold in this budget to apply to both the superannuation contribution and the Medicare levy tax hikes will be lowered, or become multitiered, along the lines of present day income tax brackets. It is a safe bet. Furthermore, without indexation of the threshold applying to these groundbreaking new tax measures, new elements for growth of revenue by way of stealth, in the form of bracket creep, will have been created. The costs of complying will be considerable but, no doubt, they will be calculated and revealed in the explanatory memorandum accompanying the relevant legislation. These increases, or new taxes, present further incursions into the household component of domestic savings, albeit to the advantage of public sector savings. The Treasurer has been scathing in comments about the deterioration of the levels of domestic savings under Labor, and with good cause. Yet there is absolutely nothing in this budget which will lead to increased private savings in the near term. The reverse is true. The two measures just mentioned are prime examples. It might be instructive if the government looked at some of the measures which it could tackle to meet what so far is merely its rhetorical concern. That the plummeting household savings occurred over a period of high inflation and revenue growth induced by income tax bracket creep, in large part, is no mere coincidence. Automatic indexation of the excise on petroleum products was also a factor, along with some pretty hefty imposts on the same commodities by state governments. More insidious, but nevertheless a huge drain on private savings, have been deliberate policy decisions which have brought forward the collection of a whole range of taxes and the associated compliance costs. A division having been called in the House of RepresentativesSitting suspended from 5.30 to 5.55 p.m. achievable, be collected on a basis equating with pay-as-you-earn collection, huge private savings were transferred to the public sector, the proceeds of which Labor then blew like a drunken sailor. The budget surpluses of the late 1980s were as much a product of the earlier collection of taxes as of raiding Commonwealth funding for the states. The most notorious example is provisional tax, the uplift factor added, which removed permanently a hard core
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Rocher
theText: On the pretext that as many income related taxes should, as near asTuesday, 8 October 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4957 of billions of dollars from households and small businesses alike. So did the prescribed payment and withholding taxes from business in general. Also contributing to the decline in household savings was the credit card mentality boosted by high inflation which permeated society generally. State and federal governments led the way by example. After all, if governments do not have to occasionally balance the books and spend less than raised, why should mainstream Australia? On top of all that were new imposts, such as fringe benefits and capital gains taxes, which raided domestic as well as business savings. So little has been tackled in this budget which will improve what the government itself acknowledges to be totally inadequate levels of domestic savings. Looking at the bigger picture, even commendable relief from capital gains taxes otherwise payable by the proprietors of small unincorporated businesses will be insignificant. Nor will the business sector in general contribute, in the foreseeable future, to the restoration of domestic savings to anything approaching historically desirable levels, some seemingly heroic assumptions about economic growth forecasts in the budget papers notwithstanding. The collapse of the contribution of private sector businesses to domestic savings has gone hand-in-hand with the raising of new taxes and the earlier collections of existing taxes over the past 13 years. As with household savings, this is no mere coincidence. New taxes such as fringe benefits and capital gains imposts figured even more prominently in depleting the level of savings by the business sector. Even imputation of dividends, accompanied by an arguably offsetting reduction in the income taxing of companies, forced the earlier collection of part of what was formerly payable on company profits in the form of dividends in the hands of shareholders. It brought it forward. Escalating compliance costs, which do not add anything to government coffers--quite the reverse in fact-also played a part in depleting business sector savings. In the wake of what has taken place, and what the government proposes in this budget, any improvement in the levels of domestic savings becomes just another impossible dream. Even if the budget is brought into surplus over the life of the present parliament, it will only result in containment of the federal government's borrowings. At the end of March, Mr Deputy Speaker, the Commonwealth had eaten into domestic savings by borrowing a total of nearly $108,000 million, most of it in Australia. Its appetite and profligacy more than doubled to reach this record high over a paltry three years, the past three years. While the new government can rightly claim its predicament is Labor's fault, it might also, in the interests of transparency, make it clear that it is in no position to do more than contain borrowings to around present levels. Such a prognosis might also throw some light onto the prospects for reducing our overall international indebtedness. No matter what gloss anyone might care to put on it, the net national debt could be around $200,000 million at the end of this government's first termassuming there is no early election. It is no consolation to know that that figure could be halved, to manageable levels if, by waving a magic wand, the government's own borrowings could be eliminated overnight. But that is a measure of the significance of those government borrowings. The reality is, however, with balance of payments deficits still running well in excess of $1,000 million a month, any fiscally responsible government faces pure hard slog. Whatever the spin doctors in either the government or opposition may say, this budget represents a very 4958 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 8 October 1996 small beginning in getting our fiscal affairs in order. It will be an even smaller beginning if some of the forecasts underpinning projected income or expenditure are not up to expectations. To put concerns about forecasts into some perspective, the three-year plan to bring the budget into underlying surplus is accepted as immutable. The underlying balance estimates call for the deficit last year of $10,317 million to reduce this year to $5,649 million and in 1997-98 to reduce to $1,548 million, and for a surplus in 1998-99 of $957 million. Major deterioration of either the revenue or expenditure assumptions, or both, is more likely than an improvement in either or both. This is because forward estimates for the current and ensuing years are at the end of the scales most favourable to the desired outcome. For example, estimated economic growth over the three years, essential to projected revenue forecasts being met, could hardly be higher, and historically they are unattainable at this time in the economic cycle, which is arguably on the wane. Further, while the short term-that is, 12 months or thereabouts-assumption for inflation seems reasonable, estimates of wages growth are possibly optimistic over both the short and medium term. Most regrettable of all, the human tragedy of unemployment is unlikely to be alleviated over the government's first term as it grapples with Labor's legacy. The Treasurer has predicted that there will be no improvement over the short term. More likely, unemployment will get worse before, or if, it gets better. To summarise, forecasts for economic and incomes growth, as well as for unemployment, are, if anything, on the sides which promote the best possible budget outcomes, both for this year and ensuing years. Normal prudence in any other field of endeavour would require best('ase and worse-case scenarios and mean averages to be adopted as the bases for forward planning. Like those before it, this budget and the accompanying rhetoric present the rosiest possible picture. A more responsible approach might be to present both worse-case and best-case forward estimates and outcomes, and not just the latter. More prudent still would be projected outcomes based on the averages of the highest and lowest in an expected range of movements in the rates of economic growth, employment, wages and the like. As it stands, the risks associated with the key forecasts which underpin assumptions about budgetary outcomes over the next three years are, to use the vernacular, all downside risks. One of the more pleasing features of the budget is the government's reaffirmation of an election promise to legislate for a 'charter of budget honesty'. When the next election is called, Treasury estimates of the then current condition of the budget, along with forward estimates, will be published. The sort of nonsense witnessed in the past, when governments changed hands and new administrations blamed their predecessors for concealing independent estimates, should not be possible in the future. The voting public will not then have to endure so many broken promises, excused because the incoming executive did not have an accurate picture of the state of the Commonwealth's accounts. Although adoption of a charter will have the effect of the opposition not announcing detailed policy until an election is under way because its promises cannot be cos ted either in quantum or for effect, that is also not necessarily a bad by-product. More honest campaigns should ensue. If so, it will not be easy to break promises post-election because of some real or perceived misconception about the true state of our fiscal condition. honesty by the honourable member for Curtin( Mr Rocher). As we know, the budgeting
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Barresi (Deakin) (6.07 P.m.)
theText: I welcome the endorsement of a charter of budgetTuesday, 8 October 1996 MAIN COMMITIEE 4959 situation that we find ourselves in at the moment is due to the true nature of the deficit being concealed from the coalition prior to the election. It is a situation which we look forward to not being repeated, come the next election. I also note that the member for Curtin was speaking about income tax reform. While there is certainly a mood around Australia, as noted by the forum that was held in Canberra last week, John Howard, as the coalition leader prior to the election, did go to the election with a basic promise of no tax increases and I believe that, by and large, the core commitments that he made were certainly upheld. In fact, the three promises that I believe were critical in the lead-up to the last election were to get our small business back on track by recognising that small business is the engine room of Australia's job creation program; to recognise the worth of the family unit; and, finally, to put young people back into jobs and address youth unemployment. Those three major commitments were made prior to the election. Those three commitments, I believe, have been well and truly addressed in this year's budget. I wish to speak to those three points. Since the budget was presented on 20 August, time and time again the opposition has accused the government of being ideologically motivated, as though the coalition's ideology were the antithesis of the values of social decency, caring for families, creation of employment, and protection of the genuinely needy in society. Members of the opposition have been attempting to portray those who created this budget as hardened conservatives, in some way out of touch with the needs and aspirations of mainstream Australian society. Of course, nothing could be further from the truth. This is a budget for all Australians, and the Labor Party knows it. After 13 years of Labor, Australia's poor are poorer, the rich are richer, and the unemployed and disadvantaged continue to surface. We are presented with this disaster as a fait accompli. We are told, 'It was inevitable.' Labor Party politicians, some suffering from relevance deprivation syndrome, claim they have all the answers. If this is the case, why did they not implement policies to fix the problems while they had the chance? They had 13 years: they had their chance, and they failed during that time. It is time to move over and let the new government have its chance. Australia is better served by the coalition. We offer real and practical solutions. The 1996-97 budget is a key part of the new government's strategy to meet its election commitments and to restore and improve the economy. Of course, we could have devised the most lax, expensive and extravagant budget in this country's history. We could have maintained a policy of fiscal irresponsibility, which was becoming something of a tradition for the Labor government. But we were elected to solve the problem that Labor had left us: namely, a $10 billion bankcard debt, a debt which is damaging our economy in the same way that Labor's regressive industrial relations policy is destroying jobs, even as we speak. We agreed to solve the problem, and we agreed to do it fairly and with a view to helping those who were hardest hit by Labor's policies: Australia's families, small business and the unemployed-in particular, the young-who have been neglected in our society. Much was made by former Prime Minister Keating of the 20 consecutive quarters of growth, yet no tangible progress was made in helping the Deakin community. There have been no long-term benefits; none of Australia's alleged prosperity has trickled down to the people of Deakin. Labor claimed 20 steps forward while the Deakin community was forced to take a hundred steps back. It went backwards as it watched our national income fall from 10th to 22nd in the world. It went backwards as the self-proclaimed workers party claimed to be hard at work for 4960 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 8 October 1996 the people of Australia while 14,000 businesses went under in 1994-1995. It went backwards as businesses struggled to pay off loans at around 20 per cent-and these were the same businesses that could have created jobs for those one million Australians who were left unemployed. In my electorate of Deakin young home buyers were discouraged from buying because they could not afford to meet the skyrocketing interest rates which increased by 17 per cent. That resulted in repayments going up by over 50 per cent-from $674 to $971 per month. As someone who has just increased their mortgage drastically in the last couple of weeks, I know just how much that sort of an increase can mean to the hip pocket-it hurts. And the people of Deakin were hurt. Yet the coalition, which is determined to help such people, is referred to as 'economic rationalists without a heart'. The Labor government foisted onto Australia program after program, one gimmicky policy after another. You name it, the people of my electorate have copped it-the accords, One Nation, Working Nation, employment initiatives. The more the names changed, the more the underlying social and economic injustices remained the same. On the way we experienced the worse economic recession since the Depression. All this while the party that was supposed to uphold the rights of the working classes was saying, 'Sorry, mate, it is the recession we had to have.' The ALP claims that, in government, they did a wonderful job; that no outgoing government has ever left an economy in better shape. The hundreds of thousands of Australians who are unemployed, many of whom recently voted for the coalition, know the Labor government had become reactionary, bent on defending the status quo which did nothing to eliminate social and economic injustices. If delivering a budget that lays a foundation for a more stable and secure Australia means criticism from those interest groups, so be it. The only justifiable accusation to be levelled at the Treasurer ( Mr Costello) and the Prime Minister( Mr Howard) is that they had the guts to deliver a socially and economically responsible budget. Let it be said that, in this budget, the coalition has reaffirmed its commitment to Australian families. The people of my electorate of Deakin, along with other Australians, will benefit from the coalition's pro-family stance. The Prime Minister promised to help families and the budget delivered on that promise. It is a recognition that the family unit had been neglected for too long by Australia's political leadership. As one commentator succinctly expressed, 'the Australian family can now come in from the cold.' The coalition's approach to family assistance as outlined in the budget is not an empty, rhetorical ploy, but a strong, unequivocal recognition of the importance of providing a society in which the family unit can flourish and reach its full potential. The centrepiece of this commitment is the family tax initiative in which families receive a $1,000 increase in their tax-free threshold for each dependent child, while one income families will receive a further $2,500 increase in their tax-free threshold if they have a child under the age of five. This is a socially responsible and compassionate approach to the hardships faced by families-and my electorate has more than its fair share of families who need all the support they can get. A report today by the University of Canberra's National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling has determined that the vast number of Australian families will benefit from the coalition's family tax initiative. The report concludes by saying that 71 per cent of families will see their weekly incomes increased; that is, their PA YE tax deductions will decrease. The government recognises the additional costs of raising a family and we have delivered on our Tuesday, 8 October 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4961 promise to families. The report goes on to say that the initiative will not benefit wealthy families. In fact, 40 per cent of gains will be made by families in the bottom 30 per cent of incomes. Once again the government is accused of presenting a slash and bum budget which neglects its social responsibilities. It is hard to understand the logic of such accusations when the government has met its election commitments in areas such as superannuation, involving an 18 per cent rebate to individuals who make superannuation contributions on behalf of spouses with low incomes; low incomes, not high incomes. For example, the government will allow banks and other financial institutions to assist low income earners by providing retirement savings accounts; these will benefit from the same taxation benefits as other superannuation products. Furthermore, the government is assisting these same low income earners by increasing the threshold of employer contributions under the super guarantee charge from $450 to $900 per month. This measure helps those who need the money now and were unlikely to benefit from the small super contribution. The budget also enables parents to have access to affordable child care. It is a budget that makes an extra $31 million available over four years to help children with special needs to gain access to quality child care. If this is a slash and bum budget then my electorate of Deakin, after 13 years of Labor mismanagement, has through its words and action given it its stamp of approval as a responsible budget and a fair budget. Yet Labor's campaign of misinformation has had its effect, to the point that certain groups in my electorate have put forward the view that budget changes will hurt parents. Let me state categorically that they will not. For example, the removal of the operational subsidy for community based long day child-care centres effective from July 1997 simply addresses the imbalances between the community sector and the private providers of child-care services. The subsidy was introduced in the mid-1980s to assist the community and since then there has been an explosion in the number of places provided by the private sector. Young families that are facing the burden of buying their first home will be extremely sceptical of claims by the opposition that this is an uncaring and unsympathetic budget. What young families will be quick to notice is how the government's fiscal responsibility and readiness to tackle the nation's debt will gradually lead to an environment in which interest rates will come down and the country will approach the level of certainty . Young families will be certain that their children will be able to grow up in a fair Australian society; a society which will have achieved a degree of sound fiscal responsibility. In fact this fiscal responsibility is already demonstrating itself. Since the election we have witnessed a drop in home interest rates delivering to mortgagees a saving equivalent to approximately $80 per month. I certainly expect this trend to continue and, as the economic forecasters indicate, there could very well be a further drop between now and the end of the year. This is the effect of a sound and responsible budget creating an environment of fiscal responsibility in which there can be great faith in our future. Mr Deputy Speaker, in the time. I have left I would like to speak to the issue of employment and unemployment. I am glad to be able to inform the unemployed people in my electorate of Deakin that the days of ineffective employment strategies are well and truly over. This government will end the strategy put in place by the previous government which saw expensive programs being funded by the taxpayer, without the certainty and often even the hope of 4962 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 8 October 1996 making the unemployed any more employable. In fact, if there was anything heartless, it was the heartless nature of Labor's programs which created an air of expectation that at the end of the day there was a job. But at the end of the day there was no job, at the end of the day there was another program and another program, and so we found ourselves on Labor's merrygo-round training programs. Our approach focuses on individuals and their needs, not on programs or program objectives. It is a person's need that is far more important as to whether or not money will be expended and in what form that money will be expended, not whether or not a specific program in itself should be justified. We will help people when they need it. Labor's approach to impose a 12to 18-month delay on receiving labour market assistance was a major mistake. The coalition will not repeat this error by Labor. The coalition, far from being opposed to quality workplace training, is actually proposing a set of initiatives that will help get this country's long-term unemployed into the work force, something that is of particular concern to my electorate, in which youth unemployment is a constant cause of concern. One hundred and eighty seven million dollars will be provided over the next four years to assist the transition from school to the workplace. I consider this particular program to be one of the most exciting initiatives in the budget-<>ne of the unsung aspects of our budget. The school to work program will ensure that young people are not left stranded once they have left school. This program is part of the government's new Modem Australian Apprenticeship and Traineeship System, which is part of the process of the reform and streamlining of Australia's training system. Loss of apprenticeship opportunities over the last 13 years have been phenomenal and, in part, we have had both the former Labor state government of Victoria, and, certainly, the federal government, to blame. The old system of technical schools in our state, which gave hope to young kids who did not want to be streamed into university, has disappeared, thanks to the Cain-Kirner governments. The former government's approach in terms of moving people away from apprenticeships and into the labour market training program has continued that decline. At the heart of this $187 million four-year school to work package lies the allocation of $80 million to expand vocational education and training in secondary schools; $40 million for workplace training opportunities for students; and $38 million for up to 200 work placement coordinators to facilitate structured workplace learning opportunities for students. In my electorate they are lining up to be work placement coordinators. In my electorate the schools are approaching me to find out more about what is happening in terms of the school to workplace program. They are excited by it. I know that the honourable member for Port Adelaide( Mr Sawford), who is on the same committee as me-the Employment, Education and Training Committee, which is looking into youth employment-also realises, from some of the comments that we have received through our investigations, that there is an air of expectation that the school to work programs will be addressed, and that the transition from one environment to another will be given prominence. Young students who are not planning to go on to university will be looking for an apprenticeship once they have completed year 12. They will be given the opportunity to gain valuable experience in the workplace while completing high school. It is an exciting program which I certainly fully endorse. Tuesday, 8 October 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4963 From my own experience in meeting with the people of Deakin, I am convinced that young people are looking for real training that leads to real jobs. Apprenticeships have for many years provided valuable opportunities for young people and the businesses employing them. The system has worked well for generations of Australians and it is important that they continue to function for years to come. It is imperative that this government be allowed to give a new lease of life to the system. The Labor Party, I am sure, will be surprised to examine the detail of such schemes; they are a genuine attempt to offer real opportunities to Australia's youth and to reveal a dignified way to enter the work force for those who are enthusiastic to work. In closing, let me assure the people of Deakin that, contrary to recent Labor rhetoric, there is no hidden agenda behind the government's policies; there is simply a commitment to create jobs for the unemployed, and a better working environment for those already employed. The budget is central to Australia's fiscal turnaround and its economic renaissance. While the previous government dilly dallied and promised substantial reform, which it was unable to deliver due to union pressure, the coalition has courageously set out a plan for the future of Australia. The government, furthermore, has announced in the 1996-97 budget broad design details of its commitment to provide capital gains tax rollover relief to small business. This measure will apply to capital gains tax otherwise payable on asset disposal on or after 1 July. The government's policy will see the amendment of the tax act so that equity investments in small and medium enterprises made by leading institutions after 1 July may be taxed under the capital tax provisions. Mr Deputy Speaker, I am glad to inform you that small business in my electorate reacted positively to the taxation election commitments that this government has either implemented or is in the process of implementing. The government has reduced the provisional tax uplift factor from eight per cent to six and it has announced an increase in the fringe benefits tax minor benefits threshold to $100. The small business deregulation task force will soon report with plans to halve the paperwork and the coalition will not proceed with Labor's proposal to force subcontractors into the PAYE net. Mr Deputy Speaker, the Australian people reacted positively to the budget. They understand that the only way out of the political quagmire we are in is through a readiness to take responsibility for the disastrous situation we have inherited from the previous government. It is encouraging to know that we have been able to get the budget message across in spite of the misinformation about the budget in the community and the opposition party's opportunistic scaremongering. Mr Deputy Speaker, I know that the people of Deakin look forward to this budget being passed, not only in the lower house but also in the upper house. Sitting suspended from 6.27 to 8.00 p.m. conservatives in 14 years are very disturbing. My view can be summarised in saying that this budget is short on fairness and full of prejudice. It is a budget that has been driven by opinion polls. It is a budget that this government has at every opportunity gone out and sold by attacking the soft targets. Never before have we seen in the lead-up to a budget ministers making announcements in the manner in which they have done. In particular, we saw the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) give a doorstop
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Melham (Banks) (8.00 P.m.)
theText: I must say that aspects of this first budget by the4964 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 8 October 1996 press conference where he released a two-page press statement and then scuttled back into his office, and the next we heard of him was a couple of days later on the John Laws program. The tragedy was that on the same day that he announced that there would be some $470 million over four years cut from the ATSIC budget we had an announcement by the Deputy Prime Minister, Tim Fischer, that the miners and the farmers would retain their diesel fuel rebate. The diesel fuel rebate in its totality offers concessions in the order of $1.2 billion per year to the miners and the farmers-more than the whole of the ATSIC budget. You see, it is sending the wrong signals. The indigenous community are prepared to suffer cuts that are fair, that are equitable, that are across the board, but these cuts to the ATSIC budget are none of that. They are targeted at the most vulnerable and disadvantaged section of the community, while at the same time the more privileged sections of the community are spared cuts. In this budget we have the defence sector immune from spending cuts. The cuts should be across the board. The pain, if it is to be borne, should be borne equally. But this government has picked the soft targets and has fed into people's prejudices. Instead of learning from the mistakes of history, this government seems to be compounding the mistakes of history. It is worth quoting the words of Pastor Martin Niemoller, a Lutheran minister who was a critic of Hitler and the Nazis. What Niemoller said summarises what I think has been the attitude of this government since it came to office, frankly. He said: They came for the Communists, and I didn't object-ForI wasn't a Communist; They came for the Socialists, and I didn't object-ForI wasn't a Socialist; They came for the labor leaders, and I didn't object-ForI wasn't a labor leader; They came for the Jews, and I didn't object-ForI wasn't a Jew; Then they came for me-And there was no-one left to object. The great tragedy is that this is not what the people were promised prior to the last election. They were promised that if John Howard were elected to the prime ministership he would have them feeling comfortable and relaxed by the year 2000. They were promised that this would be a government for all of us. The government for all of us quickly became a government for only some of us. It didn't include indigenous people, it didn't include migrants, it didn't include the unemployed, it didn't include public servants, it didn't include unionists, it didn't include the ABC. From day one, this government picked what it thought were the soft targets. That is a great tragedy. There is a sense of betrayal in the community. The cuts to the ATSIC budget were savage. They were not warranted.
